description:
Fix performance.timing.navigationStart on cross-renderer navigation.

According to the Navigation Timing spec, this value should be right after
beforeunload fires on the previous document. On cross-renderer navigations,
we were instead using the no-previous-document code path. The result is that
navigationStart is 80 - 500 ms earlier and lines up better with other load
time metrics.

I have a test case in mind that should be pretty reliable, but it will no
longer work once we update to make navigationStart 0 and base all other times
from that. Given that, I'm not sure it's worth writing the test, only to have
it removed in the next test. My idea was to have one tab initiate the navigation
in another tab, then record the time. navigationStart should be < the recorded
time. If you have any other ideas how to test this, please let me know.

See also: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=75922

BUG=104788
TEST=Added printfs.


Committed: http://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome?view=rev&revision=125035

Committed: http://src.chromium.org/viewvc/chrome?view=rev&revision=125467

messages.text:
Tony, please review for correctness with the spec.

Darin, this is the other half of the WebKit API change. If you have time, please approve this too. If not, let me know and I'll pick someone else.

Drive by comments, since I've done a lot of work on beforeunload handlers and cross-process navigations.

I'm mainly concerned what will happen in the edge cases where a page has no beforeunload, or the user aborts the beforeunload, or it's unresponsive, or the navigation gets interrupted by another.  Will we end up timing the wrong interval?

I don't suppose there's any way to write a test that shows what the intended behavior is?

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc
File content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc#newcode303
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc:303: Send(new ViewMsg_SetNavigationStartTime(routing_id(), navigation_start));
Are we sure this won't introduce a race if a new navigation kicks off?

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc#newcode1212
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc:1212: base::TimeTicks before_unload_end_time;
I find this really hard to follow.  Can you explain what the goal is in a comment?

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h
File content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h#newcode205
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h:205: void SetNavigationStartTime(const base::TimeTicks&);
This needs a comment.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h
File content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h#newcode169
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h:169: // whether the user chose to proceed.
Please explain the new parameter.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc
File content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc#newcode269
content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc:269: // is ok to do nothing here.
This comment apparently isn't correct anymore.  We have to update the start time (rather than doing nothing) even if we never ran the beforeunload handler in an unresponsive renderer?

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc#newcode273
content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc:273: }
Nit: no braces on a one-line if.  (The braces on the one below are correct.)

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc
File content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc#newcode4033
content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc:4033: before_unload_end_time));
Why aren't we just timing this in the browser process?  This approach excludes the time for the IPC messages, which seems odd to me.  (That could be a large amount of time if the user's machine is heavily loaded.)

Thanks for the drive by. It was really helpful.

I honestly don't have a good way to end-to-end test it. The new version of the Navigation Timing spec makes navigationStart 0 and all other times are relative to that. It's hard to test that it's right if it always returns 0 and there's no way to get at the internal value in WebCore. Even it was, it's still a pain to test across processes due to time skew.

Instead, I think the best I could do is have mock RenderViews, Hosts, and Managers and just unit test that they pass the right values around in isolation. I think that'd be a lot of work for a weak test though, so I haven't bothered.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc
File content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc#newcode303
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc:303: Send(new ViewMsg_SetNavigationStartTime(routing_id(), navigation_start));
On 2012/01/11 00:27:43, creis wrote:
> Are we sure this won't introduce a race if a new navigation kicks off?

Good point. I'll add a check in the renderer to make sure the SetNavigationStartTime message is for the initial page_id.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc#newcode1212
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.cc:1212: base::TimeTicks before_unload_end_time;
On 2012/01/11 00:27:43, creis wrote:
> I find this really hard to follow.  Can you explain what the goal is in a
> comment?

Done.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h
File content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h#newcode205
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h:205: void SetNavigationStartTime(const base::TimeTicks&);
On 2012/01/11 00:27:43, creis wrote:
> This needs a comment.

Done.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h
File content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h#newcode169
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h:169: // whether the user chose to proceed.
On 2012/01/11 00:27:43, creis wrote:
> Please explain the new parameter.

Done.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc
File content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc#newcode269
content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc:269: // is ok to do nothing here.
On 2012/01/11 00:27:43, creis wrote:
> This comment apparently isn't correct anymore.  We have to update the start time
> (rather than doing nothing) even if we never ran the beforeunload handler in an
> unresponsive renderer?

This raises an interesting issue. The spec doesn't go into this level of detail. Basically, the spec says:
- If there was a previous document, navigationStart should be immediately after beforeunload.
- Otherwise, navigationStart should be immediately before the resource is requested.

My vote is that we go with the latter in this situation. beforeunload may complete way after the new document is done loading. It would be really screwy if the rest of the load events occurred before navigationStart.

I've updated the code to reflect this. That means Chrome does nothing and WebCore sets navigationStart on its own (the current behavior).

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc#newcode273
content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc:273: }
On 2012/01/11 00:27:43, creis wrote:
> Nit: no braces on a one-line if.  (The braces on the one below are correct.)

Done.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc
File content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc#newcode4033
content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc:4033: before_unload_end_time));
On 2012/01/11 00:27:43, creis wrote:
> Why aren't we just timing this in the browser process?  This approach excludes
> the time for the IPC messages, which seems odd to me.  (That could be a large
> amount of time if the user's machine is heavily loaded.)

Our goal is to record the time immediately after beforeunload completes. So, we're really defending against the browser process being slow handling IPCs by recording here. The start time is needed to make the inter-process time conversion work.

Much better with the comments, thanks.  LGTM (as a drive-by reviewer).

On 2012/01/11 04:02:11, James Simonsen wrote:
> Thanks for the drive by. It was really helpful.
> 
> I honestly don't have a good way to end-to-end test it. The new version of the
> Navigation Timing spec makes navigationStart 0 and all other times are relative
> to that. It's hard to test that it's right if it always returns 0 and there's no
> way to get at the internal value in WebCore. Even it was, it's still a pain to
> test across processes due to time skew.
> 
> Instead, I think the best I could do is have mock RenderViews, Hosts, and
> Managers and just unit test that they pass the right values around in isolation.
> I think that'd be a lot of work for a weak test though, so I haven't bothered.


Yeah, that's fair.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc
File content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc#newcode269
content/browser/tab_contents/render_view_host_manager.cc:269: // is ok to do nothing here.
On 2012/01/11 04:02:12, James Simonsen wrote:
> On 2012/01/11 00:27:43, creis wrote:
> > This comment apparently isn't correct anymore.  We have to update the start
> time
> > (rather than doing nothing) even if we never ran the beforeunload handler in
> an
> > unresponsive renderer?
> 
> This raises an interesting issue. The spec doesn't go into this level of detail.
> Basically, the spec says:
> - If there was a previous document, navigationStart should be immediately after
> beforeunload.
> - Otherwise, navigationStart should be immediately before the resource is
> requested.
> 
> My vote is that we go with the latter in this situation. beforeunload may
> complete way after the new document is done loading. It would be really screwy
> if the rest of the load events occurred before navigationStart.
> 
> I've updated the code to reflect this. That means Chrome does nothing and
> WebCore sets navigationStart on its own (the current behavior).

That seems reasonable to me.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc
File content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2001/content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc#newcode4033
content/renderer/render_view_impl.cc:4033: before_unload_end_time));
On 2012/01/11 04:02:12, James Simonsen wrote:
> On 2012/01/11 00:27:43, creis wrote:
> > Why aren't we just timing this in the browser process?  This approach excludes
> > the time for the IPC messages, which seems odd to me.  (That could be a large
> > amount of time if the user's machine is heavily loaded.)
> 
> Our goal is to record the time immediately after beforeunload completes. So,
> we're really defending against the browser process being slow handling IPCs by
> recording here. The start time is needed to make the inter-process time
> conversion work.

Ah, that was my confusion.  It looked like we were timing how long beforeunload took to run.

Looks reasonable to me. Obviously needs Darin's review.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2002/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h
File content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2002/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h#newcode207
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h:207: // immediately after beforeunload in the previous renderer.
While the method name seems fine and the comment is accurate, the comment seems to assume too much about what WebKit is doing with this time. Maybe we should say something more general like "Indicate the user perceived start time of the navigation."

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2002/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h#newcode208
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h:208: void SetNavigationStartTime(const base::TimeTicks&);
In chromium style we don't omit the param names even when they are trivial.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2002/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h
File content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2002/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h#newcode173
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h:173: virtual void ShouldClosePage(
why are details of cross-origin navigations leaking outside of the content module?  this seems like something that chrome shouldn't have to know anything about.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2002/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h
File content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2002/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h#newcode207
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h:207: // immediately after beforeunload in the previous renderer.
On 2012/01/25 22:18:09, tonyg wrote:
> While the method name seems fine and the comment is accurate, the comment seems
> to assume too much about what WebKit is doing with this time. Maybe we should
> say something more general like "Indicate the user perceived start time of the
> navigation."

Done.

I'm a little leery of leaving it generic though. We're trying to follow a tight definition in Navigation Timing. If someone comes along and sees this, they'll be inclined to pass in some other value they think better approximates "navigation start."

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2002/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h#newcode208
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host.h:208: void SetNavigationStartTime(const base::TimeTicks&);
On 2012/01/25 22:18:09, tonyg wrote:
> In chromium style we don't omit the param names even when they are trivial.

Done.

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2002/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h
File content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h (right):

http://codereview.chromium.org/9166003/diff/2002/content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h#newcode173
content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h:173: virtual void ShouldClosePage(
On 2012/01/26 05:06:47, darin wrote:
> why are details of cross-origin navigations leaking outside of the content
> module?  this seems like something that chrome shouldn't have to know anything
> about.

Hmm. It's unfortunate this is exported. It's not used outside the content module. There's a TODO(joi) at the top of the file to make it invisible to Chrome.

I've updated the description to be more generic though.

Darin: Ping.

FYI, I merged with ToT because the last patch didn't compile any more.
Darin: Ping.

On 2012/01/26 23:35:51, James Simonsen wrote:
> content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_delegate.h:173: virtual void
> ShouldClosePage(
> On 2012/01/26 05:06:47, darin wrote:
> > why are details of cross-origin navigations leaking outside of the content
> > module?  this seems like something that chrome shouldn't have to know anything
> > about.
> 
> Hmm. It's unfortunate this is exported. It's not used outside the content
> module. There's a TODO(joi) at the top of the file to make it invisible to
> Chrome.
> 
> I've updated the description to be more generic though.

It seems like this function should only be exposed if it is needed outside
of content/.  Otherwise, someone might start using it.

LGTM

Sorry, I confused myself thinking the function was newly added.  Since the function already exists, then please don't worry about removing it now.

subject: Fix performance.timing.navigationStart on cross-renderer navigation.
